text: Okay so here's my situation. I live like in the middle of the state, but am interviewing at 2 places more in boston. One is northwest of the city, and the other is like literally on the coast inside boston. Are there any areas to avoid in general? Do most people commute in, or is it like DC where commuting is extremely painful?

elements.text: Okay so here's my situation. I live like in the middle of the state, but am interviewing at 2 places more in boston. One is northwest of the city, and the other is like literally on the coast inside boston. Are there any areas to avoid in general? Do most people commute in, or is it like DC where commuting is extremely painful?

text: The north and west burbs are generally quite wealthy, quite bougie, and quite white. Most people drive into Boston if they need to. Commuter rail is worse than DC

elements.text: The north and west burbs are generally quite wealthy, quite bougie, and quite white. Most people drive into Boston if they need to. Commuter rail is worse than DC

text: Punctuality was <60% in the late 2010s, so much so that the operator had to pay big fines for not meeting SLAs

elements.text: Punctuality was <60% in the late 2010s, so much so that the operator had to pay big fines for not meeting SLAs

text: Ferry commute communities are actually quite nice, like Hingham

elements.text: Ferry commute communities are actually quite nice, like Hingham

text: Traffic on the major highways (route 2, i-95, I-90, I-93) pre-covid is generally very heavy

elements.text: Traffic on the major highways (route 2, i-95, I-90, I-93) pre-covid is generally very heavy

text: And good luck with your interviews!!

elements.text: And good luck with your interviews!!

text: Thanks for the low down Jiahao. Yea so I think if that's the case I'll need to swing as much remote work as possible into the title I get. Otherwise I'll likely be pulling 12 hr days due to 2hrs of commuting, and I'm not young anymore.
